API Documentation

API Documentation¶

class plugins.api.MessageFlags(value, names=None, *, module=None, qualname=None, type=None, start=1, boundary=None)¶
class plugins.api.MessageLevel(value, names=None, *, module=None, qualname=None, type=None, start=1, boundary=None)¶
class plugins.api.PluginType(value, names=None, *, module=None, qualname=None, type=None, start=1, boundary=None)¶
DATA = 20¶

A plugin that is related to data and data exploration

ML_MODEL = 30¶

A plugin that provides some form of ML inference

NL_INFERENCE = 10¶

A plugin for generating natural language from (user) input

UNSPECIFIED = 0¶

A plugin without predefined purpose

class plugins.api.RemoteAPIModule(name)¶
class plugins.api._LocalAPI(uid, consumer=None)¶

Warning

Do not create or save an API object! Outside the main thread this class has no meaning.

async call_client_js(func_name, *args, generate_hash=False, **kwargs)¶

Call an arbitrary JS function in the client (must be attached to window) The order of the kwargs is relevant and must match the order in the JS code! If available via JS Api then always use the JS Api function.

Parameters:

  • func_name –

  • args –

  • kwargs –

Returns:

async call_plugin_function(plugin_name=None, function_name=None, args=(), kwargs={}, user_inited=False, oneway=False)¶
Parameters:

  • plugin_name – Plugin in which function resides

  • function_name – name of function

  • args – args with which to call function. Has to be tuple e.g. (arg1, arg2,)

  • kwargs – Keyword arguments for function. Has to be dict.

  • user_inited – Should this call count against the users sync call limit

  • oneway – Ignore return value and immediately return execution.

Returns:

Function return value if there exists one and oneway is disabled.

async retrieve_usr_obj(key)¶

Retrieve user based info.

Parameters:

key – key

Returns:

val or None if key is invalid or no longer exists.

async save_usr_obj(key, val, expires='never')¶

Store something on the server database. Only meant for user specific info.

Parameters:

  • key – key

  • val – val (has to be string or JSON serializable)

plugins.api.argument(*args, **kwargs)¶

Add an arguments to a function. They can’t be specified and are not optional

Example:

@plugin_init_function.plugin_method()
@argument('stuff')
def a_plugin_function_with_options(api, stuff):
    #stuff will never be None
    print(stuff)
plugins.api.option(*args, **kwargs)¶

Add optional arguments to a function. They are added with ‘–ARG VAR’

Example:

@plugin_init_function.plugin_method()
@option('--stuff', default=False, help='Do some stuff')
def a_plugin_function_with_options(api, stuff):
    print(stuff)
plugins.api.plugin_init(namespace=None, name=None, is_local=False, plugin_type=PluginType.UNSPECIFIED, is_extension=False, allowed_as_standalone=True, venv_path=None, config=None, config_is_server_managed=False, only_api=False, hidden_in_function_dic=False, help=None, call_architecture='standard')¶

The definition of any plugin. Despite the functional approach it is recommended to keep all true plugin functions (i.e. those that can be called automatically by the server) inside the same file. For local plugins this isn’t optional. The function decorated with @plugin_init has to be the first plugin function in any file! The arguments of the ‘plugin_init’ decorator define how the plugin is handled by the server. After all plugins have been discovered the function itself is called to allow the plugins to make initializations. Long calculation times are irrelevant here.

Example:

standard_config = {"a_cool_plugin_variable":42}
@plugin_init(namespace="MyCoolPluginNamespace", config=standard_config)
def my_cool_plugin(ctx, config, meta_config):
    do_plugin_init_stuff()
Variables:

  • meta_config (readonly dict) – The configuration defined by the plugin_init decorator

  • config (dict) – The configuration defined by the plugin itself

  • ctx (dict) – A context accessible by all plugin functions and those that share the namespace. Not thread safe!

  • plugin_method (function) – The decorator to make a function a plugin function.

Parameters:

  • namespace – The name used between all plugins that want to share the same process.

  • name – The displayed name for the plugin. Also the name used to enter commands.

  • plugin_type – See PluginType

  • is_extension – This determines load order if your plugin is an extension (or simply lives) in another plugins namespace and this plugin is reliant on it.

  • allowed_as_standalone – Can be used to make an extension plugin loadable even if it’s parent is not currently available.

  • venv – Either path to venv or name of pyenv venv. Forces plugin to be loaded as separate process.

  • config – A (template) dictionary that configures your plugin. It will be made available to all plugin methods.

  • config_is_server_managed – If true then the config will be stored on the server and the here provided config will just be used as template.

  • help – A description of what this plugin can do.

  • call_architecture – either “standard”, “functional” or “manual”

@plugins.api.plugin_method(help=None, callable_only=False)¶

This decorator marks a function as a plugin function i.e. the server or user can call it.

@plugin_init_function.plugin_method()
def a_plugin_function(api):
    print("I can now be called from the chat")
Parameters:

  • callable_only – Wether or not this function will be added to the text parser

  • help – Explains what the function does
